choices.text: The earth to all leads is in the right leg.
Lead I: Positive pole to the right and negative pole towards the left
Lead III: Positive pole on the left and negative pole towards the right
Lead II: Positive pole on the right and negative pole towards the left

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the placement of ECG leads?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The earth to all leads is in the right leg is the correct statement about the placement of ECG leads. Bipolar limb leads for ECG recording

questions.text: What does the given ECG show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The given ECG shows P-pulmonale. P-pulmonale is characterized by an increase in P-wave amplitude ≥2.5 mm. Occasionally, a prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1 is seen. It is caused by overload in the right atrium and often occurs with severe pulmonary disease. It is of limited sensitivity and specificity in the diagnosis of right atrial enlargement.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg. Her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


The ECG shows paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) at a rate of 180/min. In the presence of hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress, QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is warranted.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


There is depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave, and an increase in the amplitude of U waves which occur at the end of the T wave. These are the findings of hypokalemia.

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Osborn waves are seen in hypothermia. It consists of an abrupt ascent right at the J point and then an equally sudden plunge back to the baseline. It is also called J wave

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


The above ECG shows ventricular tachycardia.
The features in the above ECG suggesting the diagnosis are as follows:
• Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology (marked with red arrows)
• Absence of the P waves
• Rate >100/min- in the given ECG, it is -180 beats/min (1500/no. of small boxes between two R waves)

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Transient loss of consciousness is suggestive of syncope. As this was the first episode, the initial evaluation would include:
• History
• Physical examination mainly to check BP in standing and supine positions to rule out orthostatic hypotension.
• A resting ECG to look for cardiac arrhythmia

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with hypertension, diabetes, and asthma is found to have an irregularly irregular pulse during a routine physical examination. ECG findings are shown below. How is the risk of stroke determined in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CHA2DS2-VASC

The given scenario along with the ECG findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. The risk of stroke in this condition is determined by CHA2DS2-VASC score. The ECG show irregular QRS complexes of normal morphology and absent P waves.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

IV Calcium gluconate

The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome le. Hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcernia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old heavy smoker presented to the Emergency Department with severe anterior chest pain. An electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission revealed no ST segment changes and he was started on aspirin and low molecular weight heparin pending troponin results. Six hours later he develops more severe pain and has ST 2.5 mm elevation in leads V3 to V6. What is the management of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Arrange urgent (immediate)angiography +/angioplasty and stenting 

Primary angioplasty where available is the treatment of choice in this case of ST-elevation myocardial infarction to restore flow to the occluded coronary artery. A number of studies have demonstrated its superiority over thrombolysis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents for follow up after two episodes of collapse. The Cardiology Clinic arranged a 24-hour monitoring which reveals one episode of nocturnal paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with a maximal ventricular rate of 145 bpm. PR interval is 140 milliseconds and the QT interval is normal. Echocardiography is unremarkable. Thyroid function testing is unremarkable. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bisoprolol 

Bisoprolol is recommended as initial prophylaxis against further episodes of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation by NICE.

questions.text: A 49 year old tall thin male smoker presents with dyspnoea and palpitations. in the blood there is low K+ and Mg+2. ECG was done that is showing in the image. what is the probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Multiform' simply describes the variable P wave shapes and is an observation, ‘multifocal’ is an inference about the underlying cause. It is most commonly associated with hypoxia and COPD.

questions.text: A 30 year old patient of valvular heart is having fever for last 2 weeks. following ECG done for this patient .he was Unconscious. what will be treatment given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


In ECG there is flat line which is asystole or Cardiac arrest. So this patient will be to restart the heart and to stimulate SAN by giving a shot of 1 mg IV adrenaline. DC Shock C/I in flat line ECG.

questions.text: Given below is the ECG of a patient with breathlessness who is admitted to the emergency department. His BP is 90/56mm Hg. Which clinical finding is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The ECG show decreased voltage and electrical alterans (alternating amplitude of QRS) diagnostic of cardiac temponade.Pericardial knock is seen in constrictive pericarditis not temponade.

questions.text: A middle aged male patient came for routine check up. An electrocardiogram was done which is shown. What is the most probable finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


First-degree atrioventricular (AV) block is a condition of abnormally slow conduction through the AV node. It is defined by electrocardiogram (ECG) changes that include a PR interval of greater than 0.20 without disruption of atrial to ventricular conduction.

questions.text: A 60yr old man with history of myocardial infarction 1 year back came with complaints of  palpitations and syncope. The ECG strip obtained during admission is given. What is the long term treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Permanent pacemaker

PR segment remains same. Some P waves are not followed by QRS complex which means P wave are not conducted due to AV conduction block. Hence, Mobitz ll block. Permanent pacemaker used.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmics is ineffective for use in the following arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lidocaine 

The ecg shows irregular rhythm with absent P wave suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lidocaine is ineffective in it.

questions.text:
An elderly woman is rushed to the emergency room following an episode of syncope. Her caretaker reports that the patient had multiple episodes of loose stools and vomiting for the past 2 days. Her blood investigations and ECG are given below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
Serum sodium - 140mEq/L
Serum potassium - 7.1mEq/L
Serum chloride - 100mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen:creatinine ratio - 26.9
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intravenous calcium gluconate 

The ECG shows tall T waves and the serum potassium level of 7.1mMEq/L are suggestive of hyperkalemia. The best next step of management is intravenous calcium gluconate.

questions.text: The parents of a 10-year-old boy noticed agonal respirations at 5 AM while the boy was asleep. He was rushed to the emergency department and an ECG revealed the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Brugada Syndrome

Brugada syndrome is a genetic heart condition that can lead to sudden cardiac arrest and is characterized by specific abnormal electrocardiogram (ECG) findings. It is often caused by mutations in genes that affect sodium channels in the heart. The condition is more prevalent in males and is often diagnosed in individuals who have experienced unexplained fainting or arrhythmias.Key features of Brugada syndrome include:

1. ECG Changes: The most notable finding is the appearance of a "coved-type" ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V3, which can be transient.

2. Symptoms: Many individuals are asymptomatic, but it can present with syncope (fainting) or palpitations. In severe cases, it can lead to ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac death.

3. Genetic Factors: The condition is often hereditary, linked to mutations in genes such as SCN5A, which encodes a sodium channel.

4. Diagnosis: Diagnosis typically involves an ECG, family history assessment, and potential genetic testing.

5. Management: Treatment may include lifestyle changes, avoidance of triggers (like certain medications or excessive alcohol), and in some cases, the implantation of a cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for those at high risk of arrhythmias.

choices.text: At the end of peak expiration

questions.text: Axis deviation shown in given ECG is consistent with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


ECG shows Right Axis Deviation. 
Physiological: Lean and thin
Pathological:
Anterolateral MI
Left posterior hemiblock
Right ventricular dominance Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome
